HOPKINS WINS ARMORY MEET;
FINISHES SECOND IN RELAY
Georgetown Highest in the S. A. I. A. A.
Events—Many Thrilling Contests,but
No Records Broken—Varsity Captures Trophy With Total of 17.

Hopkins runners and field men
p:led up the greatest number of
points in the open events and captured the handsome team trophy
in the joint indoor games given by
the Fifth Regiment and Hopkins in
the Fifth Regiment Armory on
Saturday night. With a large squad
entered, of mostly experienced men,
and four men saved for the relay
team, the Black and Blue took one
first place, three seconds and three
thirds, making a total of seventeen
points. The Meadowbrook Athletic Club was second with ten
Points, Mount St. • Mary's third
seven points, and University of Virginia and University of Pennsylvania tied for fourth with six points
each.
The event of highest interest for
Hopkins was the one-mile relay for
the S. A. I. A. A. indoor championship. Virginia, Hopkins and
Georgetown entered teams, and
finished in the order named. Virginia won by a considerable margin
in the fair time of 3 minutes 353
/
5
seconds. The interest of the race
centered around the close fight of
the other two teams for second
honors. Uhler ran first for Hopkins and gained a short lead over
Georgetown; Penniman finished a
few feet ahead of his man, but Binford was not so fortunate, and Fred
Hall started last for Hopkins with
Stebbins of Georgetown some ten
yards ahead of him. Hall gained
no advantage until the last curve,
when he slowly crept up, and in a
Spectacular finish bested his man at
the tape by a few feet, giving Hopkins second place.
An object of great interest to
lovers of the sport was Ted Meredith's beautiful performance in
the half mile. The only man at
"scratch," with a large field of opponents stretched ahead of him
within a range of thirty yards,
Meredith started off with a spurt
and was in the middle of the bunch
in half a lap. Hutton, of Hopkins,
led the race until the last stretch,
when Meredith pulled into the lead
with a wonderful spurt, in spite of
his strong start. Gallagher, of
Mount St. Mary's, also made a
strong finish, making a close second
to Meredith, and leaving Hutton to
take third for Hopkins. Gallagher
had a handicap of twenty-nine Yards
and Hutton had twenty-four.
E. G. Hall took the only first
place scored to the credit of Hopkins by winning the open 220-yard

BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 23, 1915.

THIRTY-NINTH COMMEMORATION DAY CELEBRATED WITH DR. N. M. BUTLER AS GUEST
President of Columbia University Was Chief Orator at University's
Birthday Exercises Monday in McCoy Hall—President
Goodnow Reviewed Briefly University's Past
Glories and Dreams of the Future.
In his address,"Concerning Some
Matters Academic," Dr. Nicholas
Murray Butler, president of Columbia University said:
"In accordance with fortunate
custom, members of this University are assembled to recall with
affectionate regard the names of
those great ornaments of the University who are gone, and on this
occasion also to wish Godspeed to
him who has recently been chosen
to its high office of president.
-More or less that is not new
has of late been written about this
office, as well as more or less that
is not true. The office itself is in
its historic evolution the outgrowth
and the product of personality. It
depends for its usefulness and effectiveness wholly upon personality
and not at all upon authority.
Judged by the length and the security of tenure of its various incumbents at different institutions,
the office is what would be called in
the business world an extra-hazardous work. Disturbance relating to
it is not infrequent, and eviction
from it is not unknown. Nevertheless, ambition to hold it is well-nigh
universal among academic persons.
"The beginnings of the modern
office of university president are to
be seen in the careers of Tappan,
at Michigan ; of Wayland, at
Brown, and of Anderson, at Rochester. Barnard, of Alabama and
Columbia, was probably the first to
give to the office its significant relationship to general educational
policy and to the philosophy of education. White, of Cornell; Gilman,
of Johns Hopkins, and Harper, of
Chicago, were the first of that small
but powerful group who have been
able to put their hands to the invigorating and inspiring task of
creating a new institution out of an
idea. Eliot, of Harvard, is the pioneer among those whose work and
pleasure it has been to put a wholly
new and reconstructed modern
building upon an old and highly
respected foundation. It is a matter
of just pride to those who have
chosen the academic life and who
follow it that American citizenship
and American scholarship bear upon
their rolls such names as these.
."The duties and responsibilities
of the office of university president
may be summed up in a very few
words. They are the jealous care

The University celebrated its
thirty-ninth birthday on Monday in
McCoy Hall, President Nicholas
Murray Butler, of Columbia University, being • the guest of honor
and chief orator of the occasion.
It was the first Commemoration
Day exercises over which President Frank J. Goodnow has presided, and he told of the great
pleasure he was afforded in having
Dr. Butler, his "old personal friend
and associate," with him on the day.
Dr. Goodnow and Dr. Butler
headed the academic procession
which came slowly into the hall at
o'clock. Following them were
the trustees, the faculty in caps and
gowns, the alumni, headed by Dr.
Thomas R. Brown; the graduate
students and the undergraduates.
After an invocation by President
William W. Guth, of Goucher College, Dr. Goodnow introduced Dr.
Butler, whose speech "Concerning
Some Matters Academic" was a
definition of the duties of a university president and professors and
their relation to the outside world
and the students.
After the address, Dr. L. P. Barker, in a short speech, presented an
oil portrait of Dr. Franklin P. Mall,
professor of anatomy, whose work
in embryology "has brought distinction to the University."
Dr. Goodnow's address was a
brief review of the things which
had made Hopkins great in the
past, in the course of which he
called the roll of some of the scholars whose work has made their
names famous, and a very grief expression of hope for the growth of
the University in the future. He
was interrupted during his speech
when he referred to the work of
Dr. Remsen, his predecessor. Dr.
Remsen was on the stage, and the
audience applauded so loudly and so
long that the former president was
compelled to arise and bow his acknowledgments.
"The Hopkins has never been in
a more prosperous condition financially than it is today," said Dr.
Goodnow. "it now has, including
the hoSpital, property valued at
$10,000,000 and it has received during the last four years $4,000,000.
But (with a smile) I am sorry to
say that that does not mean that
we no not need money. If we are
to carry out our plan to move the

ALUMNI BANQUET AT EMERSON
Gustav Stewart, in Speech, Says That
Undergraduate Department is Unattractive—Lack of Athletics Cause.

The annual dinner of the Johns
Hopkins Alumni Association was
held Monday night on the Emerson
Roof Garden. It was attended by
over 250 persons, including members and guests.
The results of the election of officers were announced by Dr. Thomas
R. Brown as follows: President,
George L. P. Radcliffe; secretary,
Ralph Van Deman Magoffin ; treasurer, Horace E. Flack; members of
the executive committee, Joseph S.
Ames, Walter A. Baetjer, Harvey
B. Stone and Edwin L. Turnbull.
Those chosen for the Alumni
Council were as follows: Dr. St.
George Leakin Sioussat, professor
of history in Vanderbilt University,
Nashville, Tenn.; Dr. J. Hall Pleas
ants, instructor in medicine, Johns
Hopkins University; Dr. Thomas
Richardson Brown, associate in
medicine, Johns Hopkins University; Judge Allan McLane and Elgin R. L. Gould, of New York,
president of the City and Suburban
Homes Company.
Speeches were made by Charles
J. Bonaparte, Gustav Stewart and
Dr. Theodore Janeway. In his
speech on "Athletics,- Mr. Stewart
said:
"When a body of men convene at
a political meeting they all have for
the ultimate end the same good,
that is, the advancement of a party,
but underneath their discussion is
selfishness and personal advancement. This is in great contrast to
the reunion of the alumni of a college. When they gather together
it is on a friendly basis and with
but one object in view, the advancement of their alma mater. They
are like a great family who may
have different opinions, but everyone respects and believes that his
neighbor is unselfishly working for
the same good and while their opinions may differ, there is no question
of their sincerity.
That those who were responsible
for the founding and policy of the
Johns Hopkins University in its
inception were wise there can be
no question, for in a few years it
became known as the greatest seat
of advanced learning in this country. It flourished and demanded
the admiration of the world. It was
known as a great post-graduate institution. But in the midst of this
•wonderful development it met an
unexpected reverse in its revenue
and two conditions became apparent. In its hour of financial trouble
it had no alumni to lean upon, and
while it was husbanding its re(Continued on page 3, col. I).

"I have an engagement to meet
my husband and I'm an hour late.
It .has gotten me all flustered. It
is annoying to be late."
"It is so. I'd lecture him good
for it."—Ex.

The Glee and Instrumental Clubs
are now in the full swing of their
season. Although the five concerts
already held resulted in very successful affairs, both Clubs are still
hard at work practicing, with the
object and expectation of making
this a banner year in Hopkins musical history.
Two concerts were given last
week, one on Tuesday evening in
Odd Fellows Temple, under the
auspices of the Girls' Guild of the
First English Lutheran Church, and
one on Friday evening at the City
Club.
The program for both the concerts was practically the same as
that given at the McCoy Hall concert, and in both engagements, met
with the same enthusiastic success.
The Glee Club, although receiving
hearty applause for all its efforts,
made the best impression with its
"Drink to Me Only With Thine
Eyes," and its "Mulligan Musketeers." The Instrumental Club, at
both engagements played all its
music with a swing and dash which
carried the audience with it, showing to the best advantage in selections from "High Jinks" and
"Sari."
The soloists, Spieker and Geissel,
were so appreciated, both at Odd
Fellows Temple and at the City
Club, that each was obliged to give
an encore. One of the other numbers which was given especial applause was the singing of "Johnny
Smoker" by a trio consisting of
Spieker, Swartz and Uhler.
The Board of Management of the
Musical Clubs has announced the
dates -of several future engagements. The first of these is for
February 23, at Lehman's Hall. A
play is to be produced here under
the auspices of a society of Northminster Church, at which the Instrumental Club will serve as orchestra and the Glee Club as between-the-acts entertainers.
On March 2 the Clubs will give
a concert at the Franklin Square
Baptist Church, and on April 13 one
at the Baltimore City College. It
has also been announced that,
within the next month, the Clubs
will take a trip to Tome Institute.
The Board has recently been in
communication with towns in Virginia and West Virginia, and several trips will probably be taken in
those regions during and after the
Easter holidays. A trip to Cambridge is also being arranged.

resources the great universities of
the North took example from its
lead and with their ample wealth
developed their post-graduate work.
A.. man's alma mater is where he
receives his B. A. and not his Ph.
D. or M. D. The effect which the
enthusiasm of youth has upon an
undergraduate is never lost sight
of and has been the greatest asset
in the contributions which have
been made to our great Northern
institutions. About this time our
L mversity realized this and a most
earnest endeavor was made to develop the undergraduate department.
We all know what a university is
supposed to stand for, but I think
it is very human and could be
likened unto a human being, with a
body, a brain and a heart. The
body I liken unto the trustees whose
action is unselfish and self-effacing.
They watch over the body, they
protect it, they develop it and they
increase it that the mind and heart
may be encouraged and strong.
The brain is the faculty. Without
it there could be no mental advancement. They are always striving to
increase the efficiency and to impart knowledge. This is the greatest profession and the most unselfish. They are ever planting and
after four years of hard work while
the crop is being developed and
should bear fruit, the greater number of their pupils leave them and
mature in other walks of life, but
with a cheerfullness which is remarkable they turn to the coming
freshmen and start all over again.
The heart I liken to the student
body. Without the heart, the body
and the mind are useless, and
whether the heart is strong or weak
lies the future of the college. The
alumni are the food upon which the
body must feed and the heart must
draw its red blood. If that heart
has not the enthusiasm pumped into
it by the alumni it will be weak and
of little value.
What do men go to college for?
Some take the four years' necessary
preparation for advanced work,
some to be more efficient in the
study of medicine, but the great
majority go to round out their education before they enter into other
channels of work. While their first
motive is that of study, it is not the
only one. They are young and the
very contact with other men is in
itself a large education. They
should not be treated as bookworms, but be prepared on a catholic basis.
During the last twenty-five years
the percentage of men who go to
college has increased enormously
and every college whose undergraduate department is built along the
proper lines had made a large increase among the number of students. The Class of 1892 graduated forty-four men and the Class
of 1914 graduated fifty-two men.

TOME ALUMNI AT HOPKINS
GIVEN BANQUET BY DR. BAKER

Dr. Thomas S. Baker, the principal of Tome Institute, gave a most
enjoyable, dinner last Wednesday to
the Tome alumni at Hopkins. The
dinner, or rather, banquet, held at
the University Club, was a distinct
success.
The Tome alumni had an opportunity to talk of their good old
days at the Port Deposit school,
and to renew their friendship with
their much esteemed former principal, who seemed especially to enjoy being with his old pupils and
being able to talk to them of Tome
and of their work at Hopkins without restraint—no longer as teacher
to pupil, but as man to man, and
friend to-friend; for indeed every
one who has been to Tome feels
that Dr. Baker is the sincerest of
friends.
The dinner was attended by
Messrs. Webb, Poole, Myron Bagley, Leitheiser, F. P. Hall and E. L.
R. Smith.

THE MISSIONARY CONFERENCE
Delegates From Maryland Colleges Will
Gather at Goucher This Week for
a Three-Day Discussion.

The annual Maryland Intercollegiate Missionary Conference will
hold its opening meeting at Goucher
College, on Friday evening at eight
o'clock. At this meeting the purposes of the Conference will be set
forth briefly and a social program
will follow, when an opportunity
will be given for the delegates to
become acquainted with one another.
Formal announcements of the
Conference have been sent to all
the colleges and universities in
Maryland, together with Delaware
College, which was sent a special
invitation as in previous years. The
indications are that most of these
institutions will be well represented,
and that the Conference will be a
success. Hence, it is all the more
important that Hopkins should be
creditably represented.
Another question, which should
be of great importance to our student body, lies in the fact that the
delegates from out of town must
be entertained. In previous years,
when the Conference has been held
here, our students have met this
obligation in a most creditable manner; hence, it becomes, this year,
not so much a question of duty as
one of upholding a worthy reputation of the past. All men who can
accommodate one or more delegates
during the three nights of the Conference are requested to confer with
Secretary Sutton.
On Saturday, the second day of
the Conference, there will be three
sessions: one at half-past nine in
the morning, at two-thirty in the
afternoon, and in the evening at
half-past seven. There will be only
two sessions on Sunday, the schedule being the same as that of Saturday, except that the morning session will be omitted.
Although the entire list of speakers has not been made public, Dr.
Adrian S. Taylor and Miss Haggard will be the principal leaders.
Dr. Taylor has spent several years
in China as a medical missionary
and this alone should warrant an
unusually interesting speaker. Miss
Haggard, whose home is in Boston,
is a graduate of Dennison University.
The Saturday morning meeting
will be devoted to technical conferences on mission study, missionary literature and the financial support of foreign missions. In the
afternoon the needs of the foreign
fields will be the subject under discussion. The session on Saturday
night will consist of interesting fiveminute talks by men from the various foreign fields. On Sunday
afternoon general missionary addresses will be given, and in the
evening Dr. Taylor will preside.
"What is the female of the species?" "The lady on the dollar."—Ex.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 23, 1915.
THIRTY-NINTH COMMEMORATION DAY

(Continued from page I.)

and close oversight of the work and
interests of the university taken as
a whole, and the guidance of its relation toward the public. The statutes of a given university may be
more or less specific in regard to
the office of the president, and they
may intrust to the incumbent of that
office greater or less authority, but
the fact remains that the office will
be in chief part what the incumbent makes it, and the measure of•
its authority will be the force of
his personality. No autocrat and
no self-seeker can long maintain
himself in it. A great office makes
a great man seem greater -still by
reason of the opportunity it affords
him for the use of his powers; a
great office makes a small man seem
smaller still by reason of the fierce
light which it causes to fall upon
his littleness.
"The man of letters, the experimental scientist, the accomplished
student of history or of economics,
is, by reason of his university position, under obligation to represent
one aspect of university activity and
university interest to the public at
large. It is the function of the university president to represent the
university and that for which it
stands in their entirety. In any
large and complex university organization the wise president will
live almost entirely in the future.
The detailed matters of today will
be dealt with by others. He, however, will constantly scan the horizon on the outlook for new problems and new opportunities for
scholarship and for service.
"Within the university itself it is
the proper function of the president
to be the friend and counselor both
'of scholars who teach and scholars
who learn. He has the opportunity
and the privilege to bring to the
consideration of their several problems and difficulties the point of
view of the whole university, and
thereby to place at the service of
each individual who seeks his aid
the results of consideration given
elsewhere to similar problems and
of experience in dealing with them
that others have had. It is also his
duty to interpret the plans, the policies and the needs of the university's teachers and directors of research' to such governing bodies as
may exist, to hold and to care for
the university's property and to allot its income in aid of various university undertakings. All this was
clearly understood by President Gilman at the very beginning of this
University when he wrote concerning the office of the president:
"'Nothing would be more unfortunate than for the office of university president to cease to be an educational post and to become merely
a business occupation.'
"The notion that appears to be
held by some that there is a divergence of interest between those teachers who teach and those teachers
who are chosen to have particular

responsibility for the care and support of teaching is wholly illusory.
It is the true function of educational
administration to reduce machinery
to a minimum, to keep it out of
sight and as much as possible out of
mind, and as completely as means
will permit to set free the two great
and largely interdependent functions of teaching and research.
"At no time has the academic
career been so important as it is
today, at no time has it ever been
so well compensated, and at no time
have those who pursue it been offered larger opportunities for the
exercise of influence on public
opinion.
"The notion that nothing much
that is permanent and worth while
has been either known or accomplished until one's own brave self
came upon the scene makes education difficult and, from some viewpoints, impossible. Those who remember the striking lectures of
Heinrich von Treitschke, recently
discovered by England and America, and now much discussed in
both countries, will recall the fact
that he gave but scant attention to
the teaching of the history of Europe and of Germany, although his
chair was supposed to deal with
those subjects.
"What von Treitschke really did
was to make lectures on the history
of Europe and of Germany the
vehicle for the very effective and
emphatic of his own personal opin.,
ions on men and things in the world
about him. In some degree, therefore, von Treitschke was the forerunner of that now very numerous
class of American university professors who devote no small part
of their time to expressing to their
students their own personal views
on the politics, the literature and
the society of the day, while in form
offering instruction on anything
from astronomy to zoology.
"There is some reason to doubt
whether the undue dominance and
prominence of the didactic person
in the modern university is altogether an advantage. The happy
days at Bologna certainly had much
to commend them. Then it was the
students who made the rules and
disciplined their teachers; now it is
the teachers who make the rules
and discipline their students.
"The chief object of the university's teaching, of its libraries and
its laboratories, is, after all, to
arouse intellectual interest, to stimulate curiosity and to send out a
young man on his voyage of discovery filled with ardent enthusiasm, enriched by close association
with wise and noble-hearted men
and imbued with the high ambition
to make the most' of himself and of
his chosen field of study. If even
the most numerously attended university can do this for wo men each
year, and if five of the ioo become
distinguished and one of the five
eminent, that university has been
successful. It has done a noteworthy service to American life, to
scholarship and to science."

In speaking of the meet beforehand, Mr. Joseph England, official
handicapper of the South Atlantic
Association and coach of the Hopkins, team, said :
"A glance at the card to be presented tonight by the committee of
the Fifth Regiment-Johns Hopkins
games for the approval of sportloving Baltimoreans should dispel
any doubt as to whether this year's
meet compares favorably with those
of past seasons. The entries as a
whole- would appear to augur well
for the best-balanced set of indoor
contests ever held in the South.
Since last September, on the occasion of the annual outdoor championships of the Amateur Athletic
Union at Homewood Field, local
spectators have deserved races that
show real competition, and tonight
they should have their most ardent
wishes fulfilled ill this line. Before
midnight the games will be a thing
of the past, and notwithstanding the
joy and disappointment'so inevitably
present at a great athletic meet, it
is to be earnestly hoped that these
contests may serve to bring the
Baltimore public to a proper appreciation of the pleasure, benefit and
sportsmanship of track and field, a
game which ill its scope is not only
American but international. If a

step can be taken in this direction,
who would hesitate to designate the
meet a success ?"

NOT BE ABLE TO LECTURE HERE

The present war, it is to be hoped,
will in no way interfere with the
coming of Sir Walter Raleigh to
this country. As yet no news has
been received from him, and until
there is definite word to the contrary, Hopkins will continue to look
forward to the delivery of his. lectures in April.
On May 6, 1889, Mr. and Mrs.
Lawrence Turnbull, of Baltimore,
founded a lectureship in memory of
their son, Percy Graeme Turnbull,
that an annual course of lectures
on poetry might be given by someone of importance from among the
"properly qualified authors, writers
or professors of America or Europe." After some difficulty, Sir
Walter Raleigh, of Oxford, was
secured to deliver the lectures this
year. Although Sir Walter has not
announced his subject, it is believed
he will lecture on "Chaucer," as this
has been the topic of his lectures
at Oxford this season, where he has
been professor of English literature
since 1904.

23, 1915.

There is some doubt, however, as
to whether or not Sir Walter, with
sons in the army, will care to leave
England at this time. In fact, recent press reports tell how among
the drilling regiments on the Oxford campus is to be seen a company of reserves, known as the
"Last Ditchers," composed of professors and dons of the university,
many of them well advanced in life.
In this company, numbering the
Poet Laureate, Prof. Gilbert Murray, and others within its ranks, is
to be seen Sir Walter Raleigh drilling with the rest. It is doubtful
whether he will care to think of
Amerioa.
Sir Walter is known as an excellent lecturer and writer. His researches have added much to existing scholarship and he has written
not a few books of importance, including essays on Johnson, Shakespeare, Wordsworth and Stevenson.

FINISHES SECOND IN RELAY
Georgetown Highest in the S. A. I. A. A.
Events—Many Thrilling Contests,but
No Records Broken—Varsity Captures Trophy With Total of 17.

Hopkins runners and field men
p:led up the greatest number of
points in the open events and captured the handsome team trophy
in the joint indoor games given by
the Fifth Regiment and Hopkins in
the Fifth Regiment Armory on
Saturday night. With a large squad
entered, of mostly experienced men,
and four men saved for the relay
team, the Black and Blue took one
first place, three seconds and three
thirds, making a total of seventeen
points. The Meadowbrook Athletic Club was second with ten
Points, Mount St. • Mary's third
seven points, and University of Virginia and University of Pennsylvania tied for fourth with six points
each.
The event of highest interest for
Hopkins was the one-mile relay for
the S. A. I. A. A. indoor championship. Virginia, Hopkins and
Georgetown entered teams, and
finished in the order named. Virginia won by a considerable margin
in the fair time of 3 minutes 353
/
5
seconds. The interest of the race
centered around the close fight of
the other two teams for second
honors. Uhler ran first for Hopkins and gained a short lead over
Georgetown; Penniman finished a
few feet ahead of his man, but Binford was not so fortunate, and Fred
Hall started last for Hopkins with
Stebbins of Georgetown some ten
yards ahead of him. Hall gained
no advantage until the last curve,
when he slowly crept up, and in a
Spectacular finish bested his man at
the tape by a few feet, giving Hopkins second place.
An object of great interest to
lovers of the sport was Ted Meredith's beautiful performance in
the half mile. The only man at
"scratch," with a large field of opponents stretched ahead of him
within a range of thirty yards,
Meredith started off with a spurt
and was in the middle of the bunch
in half a lap. Hutton, of Hopkins,
led the race until the last stretch,
when Meredith pulled into the lead
with a wonderful spurt, in spite of
his strong start. Gallagher, of
Mount St. Mary's, also made a
strong finish, making a close second
to Meredith, and leaving Hutton to
take third for Hopkins. Gallagher
had a handicap of twenty-nine Yards
and Hutton had twenty-four.
E. G. Hall took the only first
place scored to the credit of Hopkins by winning the open 220-yard

THIRTY-NINTH COMMEMORATION DAY CELEBRATED WITH DR. N. M. BUTLER AS GUEST
President of Columbia University Was Chief Orator at University's
Birthday Exercises Monday in McCoy Hall—President
Goodnow Reviewed Briefly University's Past
Glories and Dreams of the Future.
In his address,"Concerning Some
Matters Academic," Dr. Nicholas
Murray Butler, president of Columbia University said:
"In accordance with fortunate
custom, members of this University are assembled to recall with
affectionate regard the names of
those great ornaments of the University who are gone, and on this
occasion also to wish Godspeed to
him who has recently been chosen
to its high office of president.
-More or less that is not new
has of late been written about this
office, as well as more or less that
is not true. The office itself is in
its historic evolution the outgrowth
and the product of personality. It
depends for its usefulness and effectiveness wholly upon personality
and not at all upon authority.
Judged by the length and the security of tenure of its various incumbents at different institutions,
the office is what would be called in
the business world an extra-hazardous work. Disturbance relating to
it is not infrequent, and eviction
from it is not unknown. Nevertheless, ambition to hold it is well-nigh
universal among academic persons.
"The beginnings of the modern
office of university president are to
be seen in the careers of Tappan,
at Michigan ; of Wayland, at
Brown, and of Anderson, at Rochester. Barnard, of Alabama and
Columbia, was probably the first to
give to the office its significant relationship to general educational
policy and to the philosophy of education. White, of Cornell; Gilman,
of Johns Hopkins, and Harper, of
Chicago, were the first of that small
but powerful group who have been
able to put their hands to the invigorating and inspiring task of
creating a new institution out of an
idea. Eliot, of Harvard, is the pioneer among those whose work and
pleasure it has been to put a wholly
new and reconstructed modern
building upon an old and highly
respected foundation. It is a matter
of just pride to those who have
chosen the academic life and who
follow it that American citizenship
and American scholarship bear upon
their rolls such names as these.

of the office of university president
may be summed up in a very few
words. They are the jealous care

The University celebrated its
thirty-ninth birthday on Monday in

Murray Butler, of Columbia University, being • the guest of honor
and chief orator of the occasion.
It was the first Commemoration

pleasure he was afforded in having
Dr. Butler, his "old personal friend
and associate," with him on the day.
Dr. Goodnow and Dr. Butler
headed the academic procession
which came slowly into the hall at
o'clock. Following them were

gowns, the alumni, headed by Dr.
Thomas R. Brown; the graduate

After an invocation by President
William W. Guth, of Goucher College, Dr. Goodnow introduced Dr.
Butler, whose speech "Concerning
Some Matters Academic" was a
definition of the duties of a university president and professors and
their relation to the outside world
and the students.
After the address, Dr. L. P. Barker, in a short speech, presented an
oil portrait of Dr. Franklin P. Mall,
professor of anatomy, whose work
in embryology "has brought distinction to the University."
Dr. Goodnow's address was a
brief review of the things which
had made Hopkins great in the
past, in the course of which he
called the roll of some of the scholars whose work has made their
names famous, and a very grief expression of hope for the growth of
the University in the future. He
was interrupted during his speech
when he referred to the work of
Dr. Remsen, his predecessor. Dr.
Remsen was on the stage, and the
audience applauded so loudly and so

"The Hopkins has never been in

the hoSpital, property valued at

we no not need money. If we are

The annual dinner of the Johns
Hopkins Alumni Association was
held Monday night on the Emerson
Roof Garden. It was attended by
over 250 persons, including members and guests.
The results of the election of officers were announced by Dr. Thomas
R. Brown as follows: President,
George L. P. Radcliffe; secretary,
Ralph Van Deman Magoffin ; treasurer, Horace E. Flack; members of
the executive committee, Joseph S.
Ames, Walter A. Baetjer, Harvey
B. Stone and Edwin L. Turnbull.
Those chosen for the Alumni
Council were as follows: Dr. St.
George Leakin Sioussat, professor
of history in Vanderbilt University,
Nashville, Tenn.; Dr. J. Hall Pleas
ants, instructor in medicine, Johns
Hopkins University; Dr. Thomas
Richardson Brown, associate in
medicine, Johns Hopkins University; Judge Allan McLane and Elgin R. L. Gould, of New York,
president of the City and Suburban
Homes Company.
Speeches were made by Charles
J. Bonaparte, Gustav Stewart and
Dr. Theodore Janeway. In his
speech on "Athletics,- Mr. Stewart
said:
"When a body of men convene at
a political meeting they all have for
the ultimate end the same good,
that is, the advancement of a party,
but underneath their discussion is
selfishness and personal advancement. This is in great contrast to
the reunion of the alumni of a college. When they gather together
it is on a friendly basis and with
but one object in view, the advancement of their alma mater. They
are like a great family who may
have different opinions, but everyone respects and believes that his
neighbor is unselfishly working for
the same good and while their opinions may differ, there is no question
of their sincerity.
That those who were responsible
for the founding and policy of the
Johns Hopkins University in its
inception were wise there can be
no question, for in a few years it
became known as the greatest seat
of advanced learning in this country. It flourished and demanded
the admiration of the world. It was
known as a great post-graduate institution. But in the midst of this
•wonderful development it met an
unexpected reverse in its revenue
and two conditions became apparent. In its hour of financial trouble
it had no alumni to lean upon, and

"I have an engagement to meet
my husband and I'm an hour late.
It .has gotten me all flustered. It

The Glee and Instrumental Clubs
are now in the full swing of their
season. Although the five concerts
already held resulted in very successful affairs, both Clubs are still
hard at work practicing, with the
object and expectation of making
this a banner year in Hopkins musical history.
Two concerts were given last
week, one on Tuesday evening in
Odd Fellows Temple, under the
auspices of the Girls' Guild of the
First English Lutheran Church, and
one on Friday evening at the City
Club.
The program for both the concerts was practically the same as
that given at the McCoy Hall concert, and in both engagements, met
with the same enthusiastic success.
The Glee Club, although receiving
hearty applause for all its efforts,
made the best impression with its
"Drink to Me Only With Thine
Eyes," and its "Mulligan Musketeers." The Instrumental Club, at
both engagements played all its
music with a swing and dash which
carried the audience with it, showing to the best advantage in selections from "High Jinks" and
"Sari."
The soloists, Spieker and Geissel,
were so appreciated, both at Odd
Fellows Temple and at the City
Club, that each was obliged to give
an encore. One of the other numbers which was given especial applause was the singing of "Johnny
Smoker" by a trio consisting of
Spieker, Swartz and Uhler.
The Board of Management of the
Musical Clubs has announced the
dates -of several future engagements. The first of these is for
February 23, at Lehman's Hall. A
play is to be produced here under
the auspices of a society of Northminster Church, at which the Instrumental Club will serve as orchestra and the Glee Club as between-the-acts entertainers.
On March 2 the Clubs will give
a concert at the Franklin Square
Baptist Church, and on April 13 one
at the Baltimore City College. It
has also been announced that,
within the next month, the Clubs
will take a trip to Tome Institute.
The Board has recently been in
communication with towns in Virginia and West Virginia, and several trips will probably be taken in
those regions during and after the
Easter holidays. A trip to Cambridge is also being arranged.

(Continuedfrom page 1)
resources the great universities of
the North took example from its
lead and with their ample wealth
developed their post-graduate work.
A.. man's alma mater is where he
receives his B. A. and not his Ph.
D. or M. D. The effect which the
enthusiasm of youth has upon an
undergraduate is never lost sight
of and has been the greatest asset
in the contributions which have
been made to our great Northern
institutions. About this time our
L mversity realized this and a most
earnest endeavor was made to develop the undergraduate department.
We all know what a university is
supposed to stand for, but I think
it is very human and could be
likened unto a human being, with a
body, a brain and a heart. The
body I liken unto the trustees whose
action is unselfish and self-effacing.
They watch over the body, they
protect it, they develop it and they
increase it that the mind and heart
may be encouraged and strong.
The brain is the faculty. Without
it there could be no mental advancement. They are always striving to
increase the efficiency and to impart knowledge. This is the greatest profession and the most unselfish. They are ever planting and
after four years of hard work while
the crop is being developed and
should bear fruit, the greater number of their pupils leave them and
mature in other walks of life, but
with a cheerfullness which is remarkable they turn to the coming
freshmen and start all over again.
The heart I liken to the student
body. Without the heart, the body
and the mind are useless, and
whether the heart is strong or weak
lies the future of the college. The
alumni are the food upon which the
body must feed and the heart must
draw its red blood. If that heart
has not the enthusiasm pumped into
it by the alumni it will be weak and
of little value.
What do men go to college for?
Some take the four years' necessary
preparation for advanced work,

TOME ALUMNI AT HOPKINS
GIVEN BANQUET BY DR. BAKER

Dr. Thomas S. Baker, the principal of Tome Institute, gave a most
enjoyable, dinner last Wednesday to
the Tome alumni at Hopkins. The
dinner, or rather, banquet, held at
the University Club, was a distinct
success.
The Tome alumni had an opportunity to talk of their good old
days at the Port Deposit school,
and to renew their friendship with
their much esteemed former principal, who seemed especially to enjoy being with his old pupils and
being able to talk to them of Tome
and of their work at Hopkins without restraint—no longer as teacher
to pupil, but as man to man, and
friend to-friend; for indeed every
one who has been to Tome feels
that Dr. Baker is the sincerest of
friends.
The dinner was attended by
Messrs. Webb, Poole, Myron Bagley, Leitheiser, F. P. Hall and E. L.
R. Smith.

THE MISSIONARY CONFERENCE
Delegates From Maryland Colleges Will
Gather at Goucher This Week for
a Three-Day Discussion.

The annual Maryland Intercollegiate Missionary Conference will
hold its opening meeting at Goucher
College, on Friday evening at eight
o'clock. At this meeting the purposes of the Conference will be set
forth briefly and a social program
will follow, when an opportunity
will be given for the delegates to
become acquainted with one another.
Formal announcements of the
Conference have been sent to all
the colleges and universities in
Maryland, together with Delaware
College, which was sent a special
invitation as in previous years. The
indications are that most of these
institutions will be well represented,
and that the Conference will be a
success. Hence, it is all the more
important that Hopkins should be
creditably represented.
Another question, which should
be of great importance to our student body, lies in the fact that the
delegates from out of town must
be entertained. In previous years,
when the Conference has been held
here, our students have met this
obligation in a most creditable manner; hence, it becomes, this year,
not so much a question of duty as
one of upholding a worthy reputation of the past. All men who can
accommodate one or more delegates
during the three nights of the Conference are requested to confer with
Secretary Sutton.
On Saturday, the second day of
the Conference, there will be three
sessions: one at half-past nine in
the morning, at two-thirty in the
afternoon, and in the evening at
half-past seven. There will be only
two sessions on Sunday, the schedule being the same as that of Saturday, except that the morning session will be omitted.
Although the entire list of speakers has not been made public, Dr.
Adrian S. Taylor and Miss Haggard will be the principal leaders.
Dr. Taylor has spent several years
in China as a medical missionary
and this alone should warrant an
unusually interesting speaker. Miss
Haggard, whose home is in Boston,
is a graduate of Dennison University.
The Saturday morning meeting
will be devoted to technical conferences on mission study, missionary literature and the financial support of foreign missions. In the
afternoon the needs of the foreign
fields will be the subject under discussion. The session on Saturday
night will consist of interesting fiveminute talks by men from the various foreign fields. On Sunday
afternoon general missionary addresses will be given, and in the
evening Dr. Taylor will preside.
"What is the female of the species?" "The lady on the dollar."—Ex.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 23, 1915.
THIRTY-NINTH COMMEMORATION DAY

(Continued from page I.)

and close oversight of the work and
interests of the university taken as
a whole, and the guidance of its relation toward the public. The statutes of a given university may be
more or less specific in regard to
the office of the president, and they
may intrust to the incumbent of that
office greater or less authority, but
the fact remains that the office will
be in chief part what the incumbent makes it, and the measure of•
its authority will be the force of
his personality. No autocrat and
no self-seeker can long maintain
himself in it. A great office makes
a great man seem greater -still by
reason of the opportunity it affords
him for the use of his powers; a
great office makes a small man seem
smaller still by reason of the fierce
light which it causes to fall upon
his littleness.
"The man of letters, the experimental scientist, the accomplished
student of history or of economics,
is, by reason of his university position, under obligation to represent
one aspect of university activity and
university interest to the public at
large. It is the function of the university president to represent the
university and that for which it
stands in their entirety. In any
large and complex university organization the wise president will
live almost entirely in the future.
The detailed matters of today will
be dealt with by others. He, however, will constantly scan the horizon on the outlook for new problems and new opportunities for
scholarship and for service.
"Within the university itself it is
the proper function of the president
to be the friend and counselor both
'of scholars who teach and scholars
who learn. He has the opportunity
and the privilege to bring to the
consideration of their several problems and difficulties the point of
view of the whole university, and
thereby to place at the service of
each individual who seeks his aid
the results of consideration given
elsewhere to similar problems and
of experience in dealing with them
that others have had. It is also his
duty to interpret the plans, the policies and the needs of the university's teachers and directors of research' to such governing bodies as
may exist, to hold and to care for
the university's property and to allot its income in aid of various university undertakings. All this was
clearly understood by President Gilman at the very beginning of this
University when he wrote concerning the office of the president:
"'Nothing would be more unfortunate than for the office of university president to cease to be an educational post and to become merely
a business occupation.'
"The notion that appears to be
held by some that there is a divergence of interest between those teachers who teach and those teachers
who are chosen to have particular

responsibility for the care and support of teaching is wholly illusory.
It is the true function of educational
administration to reduce machinery
to a minimum, to keep it out of
sight and as much as possible out of
mind, and as completely as means
will permit to set free the two great
and largely interdependent functions of teaching and research.
"At no time has the academic
career been so important as it is
today, at no time has it ever been
so well compensated, and at no time
have those who pursue it been offered larger opportunities for the
exercise of influence on public
opinion.
"The notion that nothing much
that is permanent and worth while
has been either known or accomplished until one's own brave self
came upon the scene makes education difficult and, from some viewpoints, impossible. Those who remember the striking lectures of
Heinrich von Treitschke, recently
discovered by England and America, and now much discussed in
both countries, will recall the fact
that he gave but scant attention to
the teaching of the history of Europe and of Germany, although his
chair was supposed to deal with
those subjects.
"What von Treitschke really did
was to make lectures on the history
of Europe and of Germany the
vehicle for the very effective and
emphatic of his own personal opin.,
ions on men and things in the world
about him. In some degree, therefore, von Treitschke was the forerunner of that now very numerous
class of American university professors who devote no small part
of their time to expressing to their
students their own personal views
on the politics, the literature and
the society of the day, while in form
offering instruction on anything
from astronomy to zoology.
"There is some reason to doubt
whether the undue dominance and
prominence of the didactic person
in the modern university is altogether an advantage. The happy
days at Bologna certainly had much
to commend them. Then it was the
students who made the rules and
disciplined their teachers; now it is
the teachers who make the rules
and discipline their students.
"The chief object of the university's teaching, of its libraries and
its laboratories, is, after all, to
arouse intellectual interest, to stimulate curiosity and to send out a
young man on his voyage of discovery filled with ardent enthusiasm, enriched by close association
with wise and noble-hearted men
and imbued with the high ambition
to make the most' of himself and of
his chosen field of study. If even
the most numerously attended university can do this for wo men each
year, and if five of the ioo become
distinguished and one of the five
eminent, that university has been
successful. It has done a noteworthy service to American life, to
scholarship and to science."

In speaking of the meet beforehand, Mr. Joseph England, official
handicapper of the South Atlantic
Association and coach of the Hopkins, team, said :
"A glance at the card to be presented tonight by the committee of
the Fifth Regiment-Johns Hopkins
games for the approval of sportloving Baltimoreans should dispel
any doubt as to whether this year's
meet compares favorably with those
of past seasons. The entries as a
whole- would appear to augur well
for the best-balanced set of indoor
contests ever held in the South.
Since last September, on the occasion of the annual outdoor championships of the Amateur Athletic
Union at Homewood Field, local
spectators have deserved races that
show real competition, and tonight
they should have their most ardent
wishes fulfilled ill this line. Before
midnight the games will be a thing
of the past, and notwithstanding the
joy and disappointment'so inevitably
present at a great athletic meet, it
is to be earnestly hoped that these
contests may serve to bring the
Baltimore public to a proper appreciation of the pleasure, benefit and
sportsmanship of track and field, a
game which ill its scope is not only
American but international. If a

step can be taken in this direction,
who would hesitate to designate the
meet a success ?"

NOT BE ABLE TO LECTURE HERE

The present war, it is to be hoped,
will in no way interfere with the
coming of Sir Walter Raleigh to
this country. As yet no news has
been received from him, and until
there is definite word to the contrary, Hopkins will continue to look
forward to the delivery of his. lectures in April.
On May 6, 1889, Mr. and Mrs.
Lawrence Turnbull, of Baltimore,
founded a lectureship in memory of
their son, Percy Graeme Turnbull,
that an annual course of lectures
on poetry might be given by someone of importance from among the
"properly qualified authors, writers
or professors of America or Europe." After some difficulty, Sir
Walter Raleigh, of Oxford, was
secured to deliver the lectures this
year. Although Sir Walter has not
announced his subject, it is believed
he will lecture on "Chaucer," as this
has been the topic of his lectures
at Oxford this season, where he has
been professor of English literature
since 1904.

23, 1915.

There is some doubt, however, as
to whether or not Sir Walter, with
sons in the army, will care to leave
England at this time. In fact, recent press reports tell how among
the drilling regiments on the Oxford campus is to be seen a company of reserves, known as the
"Last Ditchers," composed of professors and dons of the university,
many of them well advanced in life.
In this company, numbering the
Poet Laureate, Prof. Gilbert Murray, and others within its ranks, is
to be seen Sir Walter Raleigh drilling with the rest. It is doubtful
whether he will care to think of
Amerioa.
Sir Walter is known as an excellent lecturer and writer. His researches have added much to existing scholarship and he has written
not a few books of importance, including essays on Johnson, Shakespeare, Wordsworth and Stevenson.
